issues.description: Constructor parameter mismatch for PersonResource: the template's PersonResource declares a single-argument constructor PersonResource(PersonService personService) while the solution's PersonResource declares a two-argument constructor PersonResource(PersonService personService, String apiKey). This structural difference is not mentioned in the problem statement and may confuse students when they compare template and solution (and could cause dependency injection issues if an extra String bean is not provided). The constructor signature is part of the class structure (not just method body), so students reading the solution will see a different class API than in the template they start from.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the PersonResource constructor signatures consistent across template and solution. Preferably remove the unused extra String parameter from the solution so both templates and solution use PersonResource(PersonService personService). If the extra String parameter is intentional, document it in the problem statement and provide a matching bean/configuration in the template (or annotate the parameter for property injection) so Spring can satisfy the dependency.

issues.description: The constructor signature of PersonResource differs between the template and the solution. The template defines PersonResource(PersonService personService) while the solution defines PersonResource(PersonService personService, String apiKey). The problem statement discusses the PersonResource controller but does not mention any extra 'apiKey' parameter. This mismatch introduces an unexpected identifier ('apiKey') only present in the solution and may confuse students mapping the controller in the problem/template to the solution (they may wonder where the extra parameter comes from and how it is injected).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution's PersonResource constructor match the template/signature used in the problem by removing the extraneous String apiKey parameter (i.e., use PersonResource(PersonService personService)). If the apiKey is required intentionally, document its purpose in the problem statement and in the template (or inject it via @Value/@Configuration) so students can map it to the solution without confusion.
